description: The resource room teacher (Ms. Adams) discusses Emma’s experience in Language Arts with her teacher (Mr. Washington).

mails.content:
Hello Jerome,

I just wanted to send you a message about one of your students, Emma.

As you know, I have been working with Emma one-on-one to improve her reading skills. This service is indicated in her IEP.

Recently, Emma told me about her experience reading aloud during class. She told me that it was unpleasant, and that she would rather not read aloud.

I am wondering how we can support Emma, or make her feel more comfortable. I think Emma might benefit from reviewing grade-level passages in advance. Can you send me your class materials? That way, Emma and I can review them in advance.

Does that sound okay? If you’re okay with it, I can pick up those materials whenever it is convenient.

Thanks!

Danielle
Danielle Adams
Special Educator/Reading Specialist
Stellar Middle School
mails.subject: help requested

mails.content:
Danielle-

Sounds good to me. Yes, Emma did seem uncomfortable reading aloud during class. I can tell that she is struggling. She reads at a very slow pace, and has difficulty sounding out words.

It might help to review passages from our language arts text, especially some of the key vocabulary. Please come by and pick up the text during my prep (8:15 to 9:05) or after school.

Jerome
Jerome Washington
Stellar Middle School
7th grade English/Language Arts
mails.subject: Re: help requested

description: Ms. Coleman, Emma’s seventh grade math teacher, sends Ms. Adams a note about the strategies she used to help Emma in the classroom. This story is referenced in Module 1 (story 2) and Module 2 (story 1).

mails.content:
Hey Danielle,

Here are some of the strategies that I have tried to help Emma in the classroom. I used the strategies to help Emma focus in the classroom, and to increase her assignment completion. But none of the strategies have worked the way I had hoped.

  • Seated away from peers (no improvement in on-task behavior, no improvement in assignment completion)
  • Extra few days on assignments (she usually waits until the last minute to complete assignments, extra days don’t matter, assignments are still late or not completed at all)
  • A visual organizer to help her keep track of her assignments (seemed to help for a while, but Emma did not like using it)

I am frustrated with Emma’s behavior. I know she can listen, pay attention, and do her work- but she chooses not to.

See you next week,
Lisa
Lisa Coleman
Stellar Middle School
7th grade Math
Assistant track coach, Stellar High School (SHS)
mails.subject: Re: yesterday’s conversation

description: Ms. Adams sends Emma’s mother (Kathy) a list of missing assignments. This list is referenced in Module 1 (story 3) and Module 2 (story 3).

mails.content:
Hello Kathy,

Thanks for taking the time to chat with me today. Below is a list of assignments that Emma has not yet turned in.

For Ms. Coleman’s math class:
Unit 1- Lesson five, # 1-10 (pp. 15)
Unit 1- Lesson six, # 1-5 (pp. 20)
Unit 1- Lesson nine, # 1-10 (pp. 32)
Unit 2- Lesson three, # 1-10 (pp. 45)
Unit 2- Lesson five, # 1-5 (pp. 57)

For Mr. Washington’s English/Language Arts class: Comprehension questions- Fiction literature, #1-3 (pp. 5-6) Comprehension question- Non-fiction literature, #1-3 (pp. 10-12) Book report poster project

If you have a moment, please review the lists with her.

Thank you!

Danielle
Danielle Adams
Special Educator/Reading Specialist
Stellar Middle School
mails.subject: Emma’s assignments

description: Ms. Coleman discusses Emma’s accommodations for instruction with Emma’s mother (Kathy).

mails.content:
Hello Kathy,

Hope you are doing well. I wanted to check-in with you about Emma. This week, I showed Emma how to use the audio recording of her math textbook. Using the recording, Emma can listen to the text, including math problems assigned from the book.

We have a copy of the audio recording at school. Emma is free to use it during independent work time. I sent another copy of the recording home with Emma. That way, she is free to use it anytime. Please let me know if Emma has any problems using the recording, or if you have any questions.

Thank you!

Lisa
Lisa Coleman
Stellar Middle School
7th grade Math
Assistant track coach, Stellar High School (SHS)
mails.subject: Audio for math textbook

mails.content:
Hello Lisa,

Thanks for the message. Yes, Emma showed me the audio recording on her computer. She seems to like it!

Is she supposed to follow along in her book while listening to the audio? I was not sure.

How are her math quizzes coming along? Emma said that Ms. Adams is reading the questions aloud to her.

Kathy
mails.subject: Re: Audio for math textbook

mails.content:
Hi Kathy,

Yes, Emma should follow along with her book. It may help her better understand the lesson.

Emma’s quiz scores are looking better! I can tell that she is listening to her math lessons at home. Please tell her to keep up the good work!

Lisa
Lisa Coleman
Stellar Middle School
7th grade Math
Assistant track coach, Stellar High School (SHS)
mails.subject: Re: Audio for math textbook

description: Ms. Adams discusses Emma’s accommodations for instruction with her seventh grade math teacher (Ms. Coleman).

mails.content:
Hi Lisa,

I wanted to follow-up with you about Emma. Thank you for meeting with me these past couple weeks to plan, implement, and evaluate Emma’s accommodation.

I think that using a read aloud accommodation for her classroom tests has had a positive effect. It seems to me that Emma works through the problems more quickly, and with ease, than when she does not receive any accommodation.

Do you know if her quiz scores are improving?

Danielle
Danielle Adams
Special Educator/Reading Specialist
Stellar Middle School
mails.subject: Emma’s assignments

mails.content:
Hey Danielle,

Yes, I have seen an improvement! Her scores are getting much better. I am proud of her.

At our last meeting, we talked about Emma’s difficulty “focusing” during class. I drafted a sample template for Emma to use (see attached). It is a set of partially completed notes. Emma will have to attend to the lesson and fill-in-the-blanks.

What do you think?

Lisa
Lisa Coleman
Stellar Middle School
7th grade Math
Assistant track coach, Stellar High School (SHS)
mails.subject: Re: Emma

mails.content:
Hi Lisa,

It looks great! My only suggestion is to check Emma’s notes after class. Just to make sure she is using the template appropriately.

Otherwise, everything looks good!

See you later!

Danielle
Danielle Adams
Special Educator/Reading Specialist
Stellar Middle School
mails.subject: Re: Emma
